text: Tamworth is a large market town and borough in Staffordshire, England. It is 14 miles (23 km) north-east of Birmingham. A 2019 census estimated that around 77,000 people live in the town. ==History== It used to be divided between the counties of Warwickshire and Staffordshire. In 1889, the town was placed entirely in Staffordshire. The town is home to Tamworth Castle, a 12th century castle. It was the capital of the Anglo-Saxon kingdom of Mercia. ==Transportation== The town's railway station is located on the West Coast Main Line. Passengers can board direct local-stopping trains to Birmingham, London and Crewe. Cross-country trains, operated by CrossCountry, also call at Tamworth, providing direct trains to Nottingham, Yorkshire, Scotland, South Wales and Cornwall. ==Gallery== File:Tamworth_Castle_343714.jpg |Tamworth Castle File:A_view_of_the_Castle_Grounds_(29)_-_geograph.org.uk_-_872537.jpg|Tamworth Castle viewed from the castle grounds File:Ankerside_Shopping_Centre_(1)_-_geograph.org.uk_-_869837.jpg|Ankerside Shopping Centre File:Reliant_Blue_Plaque.jpg|Reliant Blue Plaque Category:Towns in Staffordshire
title: Tamworth
